newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy urges unions to begin talks on pensions.
newsitem.headline: Italy urges unions to begin talks on pensions.

text.p: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi on Friday urged trades union leaders to discuss a revision of the pension system next year, saying the subject could not be delayed.

"No-one can refuse to discuss in depth the most important social chapter for our country," he told an end-of-year news conference. "Unions cannot criticise...it is not possible to delay the discussions."

"I do not intend to smash the pension system but to bring about the necessary reforms so that the cash to pay pensions is really there and pensions are not paid out of an accumulation of debt," Prodi said.

Prodi wants to begin discussions on a 1995 deal to reform Italy's generous pension system next year, instead of in 1998 as scheduled, but has run into fierce opposition from union leaders who say the review must not be brought forward.
Economic commentators say the pensions system must be reformed to complete Italy's overhaul of its state finances.
